Award.AwardTitle: A Survey of Pulsars in Very-High-Energy Gamma Rays with VERITAS
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, and can be used to test fundamental physics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is a ground-based observatory designed to study high energy gamma-rays. VERITAS has unique capabilities, providing high sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources. This award supports scientists at Georgia Institute of Technology to carry out research with VERITAS. The group will study pulsars that emit very high energy gamma-rays to test models of particle acceleration and to look for evidence of the quantum-mechanical structure of spacetime. The group will work with undergraduates in research projects. They will also participate in the GIFT program, integrating a teacher in the group's research activities and developing classroom activities.

This award with support the Georgia Institute of Technology group as they begin the first comprehensive survey of pulsars in very high energy gamma-rays with a goal of finding more pulsars like the Crab that emit pulsed gamma-rays at energies above 100 GeV. They will perform a deep exposure of the Crab pulsar with VERITAS. This will extend spectral measurements into the TeV range in order to discriminate between model predictions of particle acceleration and to test Lorentz invariance. Photon detectors for future gamma-ray observatories will be characterized and simulation software will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this award is to understand better how pulsars accelerate particles to extreme energies. Pulsars are neutron stars that can spin with frequencies of hundreds of rotations per second and are surrounded by a strong, corotating, and donut-shaped magnetic field. It is the rotating magnetic field that induces electric fields, which accelerate charged particles to extreme energies. But it is not clear where in the magnetic field the acceleration takes place and how powerful the acceleration is. The last question is an important one to answer when it comes to the interpretation of abnormal features that have been observed in electron and positron measurements. It is an exciting possibility that these features might be due to the annihilation of dark matter particles. But a definite conclusion can only be drawn if all conventional sources of electrons and positrons are understood, and pulsars are the primary sources of electrons and positrons.

One of the best ways to probe the acceleration processes inside a pulsar is with very-high-energy (VHE) gamma-ray observations. VHE gamma rays are produced by electrons and positrons inside the accelerator and attenuate as they propagate through the magnetic field. VHE gamma-ray observations thus probe the geometry of the particle-accelerating region, they measure the maximum energy to which electrons and positrons accelerate, and they provide clues about the intensity of the particles streaming out of the pulsar.

VHE gamma rays are best observed with Cherenkov telescopes like VERITAS. VERITAS is a U.S. led array of four Cherenkov telescopes located south of Tucson, AZ. Within VERITAS, the Georgia-Tech group leads the pulsar program. The five-years long program includes a survey of young pulsars, a survey of millisecond pulsars, and extensive observations of the Crab pulsar. It is the most exhaustive pulsar observing program ever conducted in VHE gamma rays. With the end of this award, the program is halfway complete.

The survey of young pulsars is finished and published. None of the surveyed pulsars was found to emit significant amounts of VHE gamma rays. The observations, however, constrain scenarios where the emission scales with the rotational power of the pulsar. Future modeling efforts of pulsars will include these findings. The observations for the millisecond pulsar survey are complete, and a publication is forthcoming in 2020. Likewise, the Crab-pulsar observations are complete. Due to the sheer amount of data, long-term changes of the instrument and imperfections in the modeling of VERITAS require special attention in the analysis of the Crab-pulsar data. To take these effects into account, the Georgia-Tech group has led the rewrite of the Monte-Carlo simulation code and the update of the telescope model. With this new simulation framework, the Georgia-Tech group completed a full set of simulations for VERITAS on the Open-Science Grid. An effort that took more than two years to complete. The VERITAS Collaboration will use the simulations in all future VERITAS data analyses.

Pulsars are VHE emitters, but we don't know at what level. The only viable path forward to better understand pulsars and other objects is with more sensitive instruments that push the VHE gamma-ray frontier into the unknown. The Cherenkov Telescope Array (CTA) will be that instrument. Building cutting edge instruments like CTA requires the development of new technologies, which often find usage in non-scientific applications later. The silicon photomultiplier technology, which we studied in this award, is a perfect example. The desire to build better instruments in physics was the primary motivation to develop them. Now they are widely used in medical imaging - positron emission tomography (PET) -, in homeland security applications, and they are a strong candidate for LIDARs in autonomous driving. The Georgia-Tech group has invested a significant effort in the characterization and study of silicon photomultipliers during this award. The results of these efforts have helped producers to develop improved devices and users in scientific and industrial disciplines to integrate silicon photomultipliers in their applications.
